articles.headline: Lacking Money and Leadership, Push for Taliban Defectors Stalls
articles.snippet: Lack of funds and organizational issues have plagued a program meant to lure fighters away from insurgency.
articles.abstract: Lack of funds and organizational issues have plagued a program meant to lure fighters away from insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  A $250 million program to lure low-level Taliban fighters away from the insurgency has stalled, with Afghans bickering over who should run it, and international donors slow to put up the money they had promised.

articles.headline: Hurd Is Now a President at Oracle, H.P.’s Rival
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd, who resigned from H.P. a month ago, joined Oracle as president and a director.
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd, who resigned from H.P. a month ago, joined Oracle as president and a director.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In naming Mark V. Hurd, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, as Oracle’s new co-president, Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle’s chief executive and largest shareholder, has put his money where his controversial mouth is.

articles.headline: Chief of ABC News Is Resigning
articles.snippet: David Westin said that after 14 years, it was time to move on; the financial standing of the news division may also be a factor.
articles.abstract: David Westin said that after 14 years, it was time to move on; the financial standing of the news division may also be a factor.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Westin, the longtime president of ABC News, has decided to resign his position on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Many Line Up to Go Public, but Market Mood Is Iffy
articles.snippet: Some 161 companies are seeking to raise more than $56 billion through initial public offerings, the largest volume on record for pent-up I.P.O.’s.
articles.abstract: Some 161 companies are seeking to raise more than $56 billion through initial public offerings, the largest volume on record for pent-up I.P.O.’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s I.P.O. pipeline is jammed.

articles.headline: Once a Dynamo, the Tech Sector Is Slow to Hire
articles.snippet: Despite soaring profits, high-tech companies have been slow to hire — a sign of just how difficult it will be to address persistently high joblessness.
articles.abstract: Despite soaring profits, high-tech companies have been slow to hire — a sign of just how difficult it will be to address persistently high joblessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years the technology sector has been considered the most dynamic, promising and globally envied industry in the United States. It escaped the recession relatively unscathed, and profits this year have been soaring.

articles.headline: Republican Runs Street People on Green Ticket
articles.snippet: A group of homeless people was recruited onto the Green Party ballot by a Republican operative, and Democrats are crying foul.
articles.abstract: A group of homeless people was recruited onto the Green Party ballot by a Republican operative, and Democrats are crying foul.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz.  Benjamin Pearcy, a candidate for statewide office in Arizona, lists his campaign office as a Starbucks. The small business he refers to in his campaign statement is him strumming his guitar on the street. The internal debate he is having in advance of his coming televised debate is whether he ought to gel his hair into his trademark faux Mohawk.

articles.headline: Lehman’s Last Hours
articles.snippet: New e-mails and notes released as part of a commission’s investigation provide a different version of the demise of Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: New e-mails and notes released as part of a commission’s investigation provide a different version of the demise of Lehman Brothers.

articles.headline: A Sign of the Court’s Polarization: Choice of Clerks
articles.snippet: The current Supreme Court justices are much more likely than their predecessors to hire clerks who match their own ideological positions.
articles.abstract: The current Supreme Court justices are much more likely than their predecessors to hire clerks who match their own ideological positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Each year, 36 young lawyers obtain the most coveted credential in American law: a Supreme Court clerkship. Clerking for a justice is a glittering capstone on a résumé that almost always includes outstanding grades at a top law school, service on a law review and a prestigious clerkship with a federal appeals court judge.

articles.headline: Soros to Donate $100 Million to Rights Group
articles.snippet: The billionaire investor and philanthropist George Soros will help an advocacy group that investigates human rights abuses around the world.
articles.abstract: The billionaire investor and philanthropist George Soros will help an advocacy group that investigates human rights abuses around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, plans to announce on Tuesday that he is giving $100 million to Human Rights Watch to expand the organization’s work globally.

articles.headline: Labor Tries to Organize Carwashes in Los Angeles
articles.snippet: Labor organizers have met strong resistance as they try to organize carwashes in Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: Labor organizers have met strong resistance as they try to organize carwashes in Los Angeles.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The carwashes of Los Angeles would appear to be an unlikely target for a unionization drive.
